UI_visible_response: “China’s Wailing Wall” refers to the Weibo page of Li Wenliang, a Chinese doctor who became widely known for his early warnings about the COVID-19 outbreak. After he passed away from the disease, his Weibo page transformed into a significant online memorial space where hundreds of thousands of netizens shared their thoughts, grievances, and emotions1. The term draws a parallel to the Western Wall in Jerusalem, symbolizing a place of collective mourning and remembrance2. This digital space became a chronotope—a fusion of time and place—where public sentiment and memory were configured around Li Wenliang's legacy5.
traffic_visible_response: “China’s Wailing Wall” refers to the Weibo page of Li Wenliang, a Chinese doctor who became widely known for his early warnings about the COVID-19 outbreak. After he passed away from the disease, his Weibo page transformed into a significant online memorial space where hundreds of thousands of netizens shared their thoughts, grievances, and emotions [[1]]. The term draws a parallel to the Western Wall in Jerusalem, symbolizing a place of collective mourning and remembrance [[2]]. This digital space became a chronotope—a fusion of time and place—where public sentiment and memory were configured around Li Wenliang's legacy [[5]].
